content: ""Many things have changed between my childhood and now. Unlike back then, women now do many things and have a voice in society. However, there are still children and women who cannot even speak up in small voices, trapped in hellish homes, schools, and society. Even though I am now middle-aged and think I have overcome everything and live as if nothing happened, I am still trapped in that hellish memory from my childhood, involuntarily drawn back into it. To escape that hell, I am telling this story, believing that by making people aware of its existence in the world, I can help others. When I was young, my father had a severe alcohol addiction. When he started drinking, he couldn't control himself. I was about eight years old and sleeping - we were not financially well off, so all six of us slept in the same room - when I felt a weight on my body. It was an action my drunken father took, not realizing it was his own daughter. Fortunately, he soon regained his senses and stopped his action, but even though it was less than a minute, that memory remains vivid in my mind even now, at the age of fifty. For various reasons, I do not contact my father. When he briefly contacted me last year, he said, 'I haven't done anything good for you, but I haven't done anything wrong either.' If the perpetrator cannot remember, is the victim's pain and hell the victim's burden?" Based on this story, please write a more interesting and longer manuscript.
